required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Different Running Speeds of Strike Patterns
clinical_study.official_title: Analysis of the Different Running Speeds of Strike Patterns: The Efficiency of Shoes

lead_sponsor.agency: Kaohsiung Medical University Chung-Ho Memorial Hospital

clinical_study.source: Kaohsiung Medical University Chung-Ho Memorial Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this research is to investigate the differences of landing patterns while running in different speed with barefoot and wearing shoe.

detailed_description.textblock: Running speed will be adjusted with physical strength and circumstance. When speed changes, whether the landing patterns change or not may be one factor of sports injuries. Therefore, the purpose of this research is to investigate the differences of landing patterns while running in different speed with barefoot and wearing shoe.

primary_outcome.measure: The percentage of three kinds of landing patterns.

arm_group.description: Ten runners carried on barefoot test first and then in-shoes.
Ten runners carried on in-shoes test first and then barefoot.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- To jog at least three times a week, each time lasted for more than 20 minutes
- No smokers
- No musculoskeletal diseases within 6 months
Exclusion Criteria:

overall_official.affiliation: Department of Sports Medicine, College of Medicine, Kaohsiung Medical University

reference.citation: Nigg BM, Biomechanics, Load Analysis and Sports Injuries in the Lower-Extremities. Sports Medicine 2(5): 367-379, 1985. Hasegawa H, Yamauchi T, Kraemer WJ. Foot strike patterns of runners at the 15-km point during an elite-level half marathon.Journal Strength Cond Research,21(3): 888-893, 2007. Cavanagh PR, Lafortune MA. Ground reaction forces in distance running. J Biomech 13(5): 397-406, 1980 Shih Y, L KL, TY Shiang. Is the foot striking pattern more important than barefoot or shod conditions in running? Gait Posture 38(3): 490-494, 2013.
